awd_abstract_narration:
The American Association for the Advancement of Science (AAAS) and the National Science Foundation (NSF) will continue its collaboration in providing to early- and mid-career scientists and engineers experiential professional development and public service fellowships via the AAAS Science and Technology Fellowship (STPF) Program. The STPF program objectives are to: a) educate scientists and engineers on the intricacies of federal policy making; b) provide information and analyses that support decision makers confronting challenges that involve scientific and technological issues; c) empower civic engagement and leadership by scientists and engineers by enhancing their skills to assess, communicate and apply science and technology in policy contexts; and d) increase the involvement and visibility of scientists and engineers in the policy realm and foster positive exchange between scientific professionals, policymakers and regulators. In the long-term, the STPF program seeks build science and engineering leadership capacity to support evidence-based policy and practice by developing policy-savvy scientists and engineers who understand government and policy making well-trained to develop solutions to the nation's challenges. 

Fellows are selected by the AAAS annually through a highly-competitive process and placed for one-year fellowships in offices throughout the NSF. Under the guidance of mentors, Fellows work on projects of mutual interest to the Fellow and the host office. Fellowship activities allow the Fellows to gain insight into how national science and technology policy goals are translated into programs at NSF that reflect the agency's mission. The AAAS provides an orientation on executive branch and congressional operations, as well as knowledge- and skill-building professional development seminars throughout the year. The AAAS also conducts extensive outreach for recruitment, including scientists and engineers from traditionally underrepresented populations; administers a rigorous merit review process to identify finalists; matches fellows with host offices; and provides support for the fellows throughout their fellowships.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
PROJECT: AAAS Science & Technology Policy Fellowships at NSF, September 1, 2022 to December 31, 2022

Overview: The American Association for the Advancement of Science (AAAS) placed 48 fellows at NSF through its Science & Technology Policy Fellowships program (STPF), over the period of December 1, 2022, to December 31, 2022. The broad objective is to build S&T leadership to support evidence-based policy and practice. AAAS provides policies and guidelines; conducts recruitment, selection and placement; programmatic management; administration of fellowship support; and implementation of professional development programs fellowship for the fellows at NSF. Now in its 50th year, STPF has extensive experience operating federal policy opportunities for scientists and engineers. AAAS administers the 1 to 2-year fellowships assignments, which augment NSF?s scientific and technical expertise. Fellows are selected through a rigorous merit review process. They are supported with a professional development program, including an orientation, seminars, skill-building workshops, career enhancement sessions, and gatherings to foster resource sharing and collaboration. Fellows learn through immersion in NSF host offices the processes for analyzing, developing, and implementing policies and programs that affect the national scientific agenda. They engage in a range of research programs, communication and education initiatives across NSF?s focus areas. Fellows contribute expertise, analytical talent, time, energy, and external perspectives and connections to NSF??s core purpose to promote achievement and progress in science and engineering and enhance the potential for research and education to contribute to the Nation.

Intellectual Merit: The S&T Policy Fellowships are opportunities for professional development and public service, as part of the AAAS mandate to ?advance science and serve society.? The aim is to foster evidence-based policy and practice by engaging scientists and engineers from a broad range of disciplines, backgrounds and career stages to directly contribute knowledge and analytical skills for well-informed federal policy actions; to learn first-hand about policymaking and implementation at the federal level; and to build leadership capacity for a strong S&T enterprise. AAAS has placed over 404 of its S&T Policy Fellows at NSF over 22 years. Annual reports of fellows? activities highlight a wide range of projects and contributions to NSF initiatives, and a gain of knowledge, experience and networks that enable fellows to move into positions of greater influence.

Broader Impacts: Since 1973, more than 4,500 scientists and engineers have been through the program: ~3,000 in the executive branch, ~1,500 fellows in the legislative branch, and the judicial Branch program has placed six fellows at the Federal Judicial Center. Feedback attests that the experience enhances capacity to engage more effectively on a broad spectrum of issues with a range of audiences. Fellows? supervisors also affirm the value of fellows? contributions to host offices and NSF broadly. AAAS promotes the activities of its fellows via its website, an online newsletter, and through outreach presentations. Fellows at NSF have gone on to a broad range of positions in academia, government, nonprofits and industry. They carry into their future pursuits a deep understanding of U.S. government programs and initiatives and the many factors affecting policy.  STPF fellows have gained experience to comprehend the critical importance of research, applied science, and outreach that address societal challenges, support public policy, and contribute to the wellbeing of the nation and citizens around the world. Current and future cohorts of fellows create a growing network of STEM leaders to help improve policy outcomes and to mentor new generations of scientists and engineers with the skills to communicate and apply science to support improved policy.


Last Modified: 04/12/2023
Modified by: Rashada Alexander
